Isn't the irony delicious? Mr. Hubbard argues for a balanced budget amendment, but when handed a projected budget surplus by Clinton, the Hubbard-advised Bush Administration gave it up and more in deficit-creating tax cuts for the wealthy.

Do as I say, not as I do, eh?

Mr. Hubbard, an amendment requiring a balanced budget is a bad idea. As one of the architects of the disastrous Bush tax cuts, your tax policy has caused our deficits to balloon. It was unwise policy.

Deficit spending during times of recession is necessary. The stimulus of 2009-10 help save or create millions of jobs, but prominent economists like Joseph Stiglitz pointed out the stimulus was too small. That’s why we are limping along in this economy. Stiglitz made the case for more stimulus in a 2010 interview with Democracy Now:

“If we don’t stimulate the economy, the economy is going to get WEAKER. When the economy gets weaker, tax revenues go down and expenditures go up. Already, more than 40 million Americans are on food stamps. The number of people on Medicaid is reaching record levels. So, revenues go down, expenditures go up, deficits get worse. If you stimulate the economy, then people get jobs, they spend money, tax revenues go up.

“If we spend the money on investments in education, technology, infrastructure, you GROW the economy in the short run from the stimulus, you GROW the economy in the long term because of the returns that you get on these investments. Think about this from the point of view of a firm. If you are a firm and you could borrow at 0 to 2/12 percent, which is what the government can borrow, and you have investment opportunities that yield 10, 15, 20 percent, you would be irresponsible, you would be foolish, not to undertake those investments.”
@Mike Winerip: you are exploiting other people's pain here -- plain and simple.

The only people we write about are people willing to be interviewed and only cases where both members of the relationship are comfortable using their names. And we've worked hard at coming up with a format that isn't prurient, that like any good writing, among other things, sheds light and provides insight. So no, I don't think it's any more exploitative than Our Making It Last pieces which feature long term relationships-- including the dark moments that have threatened the partnership. Divorce is widespread in our society, and we expect people will read these pieces and find things that strike a common chord, that they can identify with-- whether they're divorced or not. Finding commonality encourages empathy, and empathy is one of the things that separates humans from animals.

When I was in school, we were taught that the Great Depression in the US was ended by those two brilliant economists Adolph and Tojo, who alone were responsible for cutting the US unemployment rate from more than 15% to less than 2%.

One of the comments made several years ago to an earlier column by Prof. Krugman pointed out how my liberal teachers had lied: during WWII, the real US unemployment rate was more than 50%!

The comment vehemently disagreed with the paper by Michael R Darby ("Three-and-a-Half Million U.S. Employees Have Been Mislaid") that said government workers should not have been counted as unemployed during the Depression, so the commentator counted as unemployed all those working for the US government during the war.

Given that line of reasoning, along with Ayn Rand's view that corruption and graft are impossible in any nation on a strict gold standard (no bimetallism for her), one gets the major foundations of the economic view shared by those American voters who put Rand Paul in the Congress and who want to see him as chief executive.

Those voters reject Profs Krugman and Darby, and want a return to the halcyon days of the 19th century. Preferably before that liberal Lincoln.

One cannot question the deep insights of such voters.

Because they don't have any.

How does Krugman say with a straight face

"I’d argue that the experience of the past 15 years, first in Japan and now across the Western world, shows that Keynes was right and Friedman was wrong about the ability of unaided monetary policy to fight depressions."

Last time I checked Japan has had some serious deflation/disinflation during their last 2 decades of economic malaise along with some serious fiscal budget deficits. Milton Friedman, the man who coined the term "helicopter drop" was all about getting newly printed bills straight to the people in order to forgo such a calamity as deflation. Yes, Japan invented QE (which only affected the monetary base and not cash in circulation since banks were all zombies not lending) but Krugman is taking a country that did everything Keynes said ( ran HUGE fiscal deficits) and nothing Friedman said (they tolerated falls in the price level) and makes it off as if that somehow vindicates Keynes over Friedman.

Dear Mr. Wenz,

I like "Report the reality".

Let's do exactly that. All the CAGW panic is in the extrapolations done in modelling studies.

Strip that away, look at the reality and the panic dwindles to peanut size in the mind.

Back when dinosaurs still trod the earth and my hair was still black, my history of science teacher told me "Good scientists interpolate their data with caution. Good scientists extrapolate -never!!!"

Yet what is the entire mainstream climate science establishment engaged in, if not one monumental exercise in extrapolating their modelling results decades into the future?

Look at James Hansen's classic 1988 paper and the associated testimony before congress. Twenty-five years is long enough to show clearly that Hansen's modeling extrapolations were so far wrong that (mostly) ignoring him was in fact the correct policy response to a truly flawed prediction.

I challenge your assertion that we are in the grip of megadroughts. The Modified Palmer Drought Index tells a different story, and today's periodic droughts are nothing compared to the 200 year drought which wrecked the Cliff Dwellers civilization in the Four Corners region.

Superstorms? Ryan Maue's tropical storm energy index has been falling steadily for the last ten years. We are now in August with NOAA downgrading the intensity of the hurricane season.

Forest fires? Nothing compared to The Big Burn of 1912.

Yes let's report the reality. Start with your own posts.

@Doked,
It's hard to misconstrue the general hostility to neuroscience expressed in Fong's column. The "fair and balanced" ploy doesn't mean he has considered both sides. In your own comment, it's hard to believe that anyone can be an "ardent advocate of neurophysiological approaches" and then call brain science an intellectual, social and moral danger.

Reductionism has become one of those boo-words that castigates those who are trying to untangle the mechanisms and processes of brain function. Understanding the mechanism does not diminish human beings or reduce them to their component parts.

Human history is a shameful catalog of the ways in which we have behaved toward others because we lacked basic understanding. The other day the pope appeared to performed an impromptu exorcism. It seems we still have a long way to go.

@gemli Apparently it's not so hard, because you've done it twice now.  Fong's article is advocating that research continues in a way that is not meant to, practically or philosophically, replace social progress.  History is also a shameful catalog of social and political misuse of scientific advances, of scientists' regrets at having offered such research over to governments or corporate interests, and the misuse (and outright twisting) of scientific theories to promote political or social propaganda.  It's probably about time that we, as a culture, began to take into account how certain science should be absorbed by society.  It's not a question of whether we conduct the research or not - progress cannot be stopped, only slowed.  The question is what kind of preparations we should make in anticipation of the results.  And Fong is advocating openness and accessibility, and honesty with the results, not hoarding and controlling the results via corporate interests and corporate propaganda.

When I started this I was sure I'd fundamentally disagree with it, for many of the reasons advanced by House, gemli, and Michael.  However, as I read it, I became convinced by it, and I think the three commentators I mention have misunderstood it (Michael's comments are, I think, just irrelevant; the other two actively misconstrue it, although I think inadvertently).  What the article is saying is that a danger of neurological research and interpretations is that they preempt reseach and theororizing about other, psychosocial, factors in disease, and like abstract expressionism as an alternative to social realism as an artistic approach in the 1930s, serves the interests of the established socioeconomic order in ways its proponents not only don't intend, but don't even realize.  Since I'm an ardent advocate of neurophysiological approaches to psychocultural phenomena in my scholarly work, I thank the author for his insightful critique, and urge all in this endeavor to take seriously its implications.  Reductionism is not just an intellectual, but a social, and ultimately moral, danger.

Already Americans are ignoring psychosocial and socioeconomic factors, and known preventive measures, for dealing with psychological dysfunctions. We just put the dysfunctional individuals into our ever-expanding prison systems.  We've already sold out to Chevron, Proctor & Gamble, Merck, other corporations, and profit-seeking investors.
